videos.title: A Gravel Weekend with Mammoth Tuff(4K)
videos.description:
GBC returns to our favorite event showing off the Eastern Sierra to a special guest enjoying a gravel weekend at Mammoth Tuff.: https://gravelbikecalifornia.com/gravel-weekend-with-mammoth-tuff

Additional Camera: @bikeobsession

Learn more about Mammoth Tuff:
https://www.tuff.ventures/mtuff

Gravel Bike California Shop:
https://gravelbikecalifornia.threadless.com/

Support Gravel Bike California on Patreon:
https://www.patreon.com/gravelbikecalifornia

Find more routes on our map of Gravel Guides across California:
https://gravelbikecalifornia.com/california-gravel-guides/

Mammoth Tuff short course:
https://ridewithgps.com/routes/48375492

Follow us on:
https://www.instagram.com/gravelbikecalifornia
https://www.facebook.com/groups/gravelbikecalifornia
https://www.strava.com/clubs/gravelbikecalifornia

0:00 - 1:17 Intro
1:17 - 4:08 Onion Valley Rd
4:08 - 6:21 Minaret Vista Single Track
6:21 - 9:55  Shakedown & Mammoth Buff
9:55 - 13:17  Tuff Sandy Start
13:17 - 17:55 Owens Valley Rd
17:55 - 20:11 Sawmill to Post-Ride
20:11 - 22:22 Mammoth Lakes & Raffle

videos.title: Mammoth Tuff Gravel Guide (4K)
videos.description:
Gravel Bike California heads up to Mammoth Lakes for the inaugural Mammoth Tuff the embraces the beauty and unique riding of the Eastern Sierra. https://gravelbikecalifornia.com/mammoth-tuff-gravel-guide

Additional Footage: @bikeobsession

Gravel Bike California Shop:
https://gravelbikecalifornia.threadless.com/

Support Gravel Bike California on Patreon:
https://www.patreon.com/gravelbikecalifornia

Mammoth Tuff: www.https://mammothtuff.com/
Amanda Nauman: https://www.instagram.com/amanda_panda_/
Dave Sheek: https://www.instagram.com/dsheek/

Find more routes on our map of Gravel Guides across California: https://gravelbikecalifornia.com/california-gravel-guides/

Follow us on:
https://www.instagram.com/gravelbikecalifornia
https://www.facebook.com/groups/gravelbikecalifornia
https://www.strava.com/clubs/gravelbikecalifornia

Proper Route file:
GBC Pre-ride-pre-ride: https://ridewithgps.com/routes/41105570
Mammoth Tuff Pre-ride: https://ridewithgps.com/routes/41013302
Mammoth Tuffer route: https://ridewithgps.com/routes/41120906

0:00 - 2:36 Intro with Event Organizers Amanda & Dave
2:36 - 4:03 Rock Creek Excursion
4:03 - 6:26 GBC Minaret Vista Pre Ride
6:26 - 8:30 Mammoth Tuff Pre Ride
8:30 - 9:30 Surviving Mammoth Buff
9:30 - 11:02 Starting the Mammoth Tuffer Route
11:02 - 13:26 Owens River Road & Benton Crossing
13:26 - 15:22 Casa Diablo Mine Loop
15:22 - 17:54 Deer Spring climb & sandy survival
17:54 - 19-12 Benton back to Hot Creek
19:12 - 21:35 Sawmill Creek home stretch & closing ceremonies

well as Dave and Danny from gravel Stoke
as we soon turn back to dirt for our
most significant climb of the day
rising up Deer Springs Road at 5.4
percent over three and a half miles
the start was tame but we had been
exposed for over 40 miles and while this
isn't the most colossal climb on paper
the underlying elements of the day
started kicking in as a steeper Graves
wasn't punishing enough on itself
but also making a more sustained effort
at altitude
on a Surface not properly rewarding your
struggle with trees just far enough back
not to provide shade and few visual cues
where you're headed perseverance was the
watchword as nearing the peak was
signaled High plane shifter style also
shot in this Forest while reaching the
Apex and almost 8 000 feet is worthy of
a stop if not just to see where your
final 25 miles LED
while a straightish five mile descent
may feel like compensation for your
effort it's best to let someone else go
first with the first half mile averaging
over 11 percent where your braking
skills will come in handy on top of some
tap dancing as well and as the grades
start to let up I could parse out Tire
widths without even asking also not a
managing climbing let alone driving in
the opposite direction
but here we are
strangest phenomena was the amount of
pedaling even though gravity would
suggest otherwise allowing selfie action
to grade that normally wouldn't permit
as most would expect to conserve energy
and not sweating out looking at the root
unless you were smart enough to double
up tandem style
but I'm glad I focused my attention
elsewhere
as a Sierra guided my thoughts away from
the hardships
we returned onto flattish Benton
Crossing but now we had a new Foe and a
heavy headwind so the smart move was
jumping onto any train passing by seeing
their time trial skills were prudent and
as the band around the Owens River took
us Due West
the group properly abandoned our direct
Pace line with an Echelon formation the
only way to battle through
turning back onto Owens River Road the
focus is getting through the last 15
miles and your eagerness is combated by
heavier gusts on top of a roadway that
looks endless
but going left onto Hot Creek Hatchery
Road felt like progress was being made
not just by confirming it was properly
named but that we were not too far from
the Aid Station and while most headed
there I couldn't pass up returning to
one of the most unique spots around
to see the pureness of Blue from this
historic geological site thanks to the
bed of magma below and if other cyclists
wanted to leave this all to myself so be
it as I found them at the aid station
right above with people needing a break
even with 10 miles left as so says the
experts
while the rest of this dirt sector looks
straightforward Vic would say this was
glass half full talk as grinding your
gears was a requirement and the
downhills didn't seem that much faster
with even the pavement not feeling like
a remedy but at least my bulby torso is
effective at blocking wind as turning
onto the 395 proved it kept intensifying
the closer we got to Mammoth Lakes at
levels I've never experienced before
and moving over to the parallel Road had
pretty much the same effect just without
the traffic
heading under the 395 seemed like the
home stretch revisiting Sawmill Road
from the day before and while I
remembered this is less than two miles
of climbing on dirt we were changed
people since yesterday as now I could
hear the Sam laughing back at us or
maybe we just wanted to finish after
turning onto Main Street meant just a
mile back wiggling our way into the
village good to see friends and
well-wishers at the finish line
oh and Troy too
super happy to post game at shelter
Distillery where food and beverages were
tastily provided but festivities
actually closed on Sunday where the
winners were crowned and a deep prize
pool for the raffle looking like a
buffet with Danny coming out on top
walking away with a Niner frame and I'd
give a big thanks to Amanda and Dave but
they are probably still reading off
raffle numbers
so Mammoth tough was more than it was an
experience everyone that came out here
was able to catch ecu's I'm sure they're
sharing with their friends family and
bring them along next year
Eastern Sierra has not been covered
enough and David Amanda should be very
proud how they expose people to this
we knew it wasn't going to be easy but
the physical effort on top of all the
festivities
oh what a complete weekend
anyways you want to kind of support our
adventures go ahead and hit the
Subscribe button or go to our shop or
support us on patreon so we can bring
you more
in the state of dirt

videos.title: Two new Pinarello gravel bikes tested at Mammoth Tuff with Chris Johnston
videos.description:
The Pinarello Grevil F and Dogma GR are the two latest gravel bikes from the Italian brand. Chris Johnston of Outdoor Bros and I raced these bikes at Mammoth Tuff in Mammoth Lakes, California. 

Outdoor Bros: https://www.youtube.com/@outdoorbros_/videos
Pinarello gravel bikes on Bike Tires Direct: https://tinyurl.com/3tb62brk

Want to see what I'm testing and where? Follow me
on Strava: https://www.strava.com/athletes/ben-delaney
on Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/ben_delaney

--
The Ride is supported in 2025 by:
Castelli clothing: https://www.castelli-cycling.com/US/en/
HOVERAir self-flying cameras: https://amzn.to/3ZCzb9V
Perc coffee: https://tinyurl.com/fjr7nurr (save 15% with code 'ride15')
Saris racks: https://saris.com/collections/racks# (save 15% with code 'ben15')
Silca maintenance: https://silca.cc/ (save 10% with code 'theridewithbenjune2025')
BikeTiresDirect: https://tinyurl.com/yc7vxujh (save 10% with code 'THERIDE') 
The Cyclist Lawyer: https://www.thecyclist-lawyer.com/
Shimano shoes & glasses: http://tinyurl.com/ye274tep
Feedback Sports stands & tools: https://bit.ly/3S9Dq8r

videos.title: One 'Tuff' Gravel Ride: The Mammoth Tuff!
videos.description:
Gravel bikes in the Sierra Nevada Mountains of the Eastern Sierras? You bet, and @oldguyandabike was there to sample the soft soils and wide vistas of the best that Mammoth Mountain had to offer.

Come on along, hell or not!

Mammoth Tuff Central - https://www.tuff.ventures

Follow me on Strava - https://www.strava.com/athletes/1939512

Affiliate links and discount codes: Support those who support us -
Redshift Sports - https://redshiftsports.com?aff=42

videos.title: Mammoth TUFF Weekend Gravel Race Documentary
videos.description:
Back for my second year taking on the Mammoth TUFF. This is a 40+ mile gravel race in the heart of Mammoth Lakes California. 

Again this year I camped waking up in 35° weather, pretending I’m smoking cigarettes with the warm air exiting my lungs while I wait for my coffee to brew. This year I was joined by my wife and daughter which was an absolute blast seeing them waving my CaliDOMESTIQUE flag for me at the finish line. It was that extra little encouragement that I needed to keep going. 

Our first evening, a bear visited our campsite exchanging all my friend’s meat in his cooler for paw prints. After we got warm and started moving, we jumped in the truck to explore June Lake and then over to the village for packet pickup. 

The morning of race day, I struggled to get up in the cold, and what was even more terrifying was trying to slide into ice cold cycling gear. We left our campsite at 7:40am for the 8:20am start time. 

There was a controlled pace and vehicle lead out until we turned off the main road and headed for dirt. We were immediately welcomed with a grade that only seemed to garner more elevation. Once we crested the first climb of the day, we had a chunky fast descent. Me being me, I was trying to be super quiet at camp and closed the car door on my thumb. It immediately bruised up and was throbbing. The vibrations coming from the downhill was not helping my thumb. My right hand went numb and I could feel my heart beat in my thumb. But I kept going. This is where I lost a bit of time, but made it up on the flats. 

Any other course, the crushed gravel roads would be mundane, but any direction you look, you’re blessed with mountain formations anywhere you look. 

The last part of the section last year had a deep sandy area where it took a miracle not to come to a stop and walk your bike. This year, it was replaced with some fun single track before putting you back in the final road climb back to the Village. 

From the campsite to the village we knew what incline was awaiting us as we tackled the climb once again for the final time of the day. Once I made that final right turn towards the finish line, I immediately saw my daughter waving my flag. I almost didn’t even notice the flag because I was drawn to the biggest smile on her face. 

After we redeemed our meal and drink ticket, we rode back to camp and jumped into the jacuzzi for some much needed R&R. We had another lunch and then headed back to the village for some Mammoth Brewery IPA at GOMEZ Mexican restaurant in the heart of the village. 

Sunday came way too soon, and it was time to pack up and head home. We stopped in Bishop for some baked goods, and then caffeine in Line Pine before making our 4 hour drive back home. 

Thanks to everyone who supported me for this video and I can’t wait for the next one.
